sen.j: 城南宮（じょうなんぐう）は、京都市伏見区にある神社である。
sen.e: Jonan-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.
Jonan-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.
Jonan-gu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は府社。
sen.e: It was listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and ranked as a Fusha (prefectural shrine) under the old shrine classification system.
It was listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and ranked as a Fusha (prefectural shrine) under the old shrine classification system.
It was listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and ranked as a Fusha (prefectural shrine) under the old shrine classification system.

sen.j: 「方除の大社」として知られている。
sen.e: The shrine is also known as "Hoyoke no Taisha".
The shrine is also known as "Hoyoke no Taisha".
The shrine is also known as 'Hoyoke no Taisha.'
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined deities

sen.j: 息長帯日売命（神功皇后）、八千歳神（大国主神）、国常立尊を主祭神とし、他に天照大神、応神天皇、別雷神、大山咋神、天児屋根命、保食神を祀る。
sen.e: The main deities are Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto (Empress Jingu), Yachitose no Kami (Okuninushi no Kami) and Kunitokotachi no Mikoto which are enshrined with Amaterasu Omikami, Emperor Ojin, Wake-Ikazuchino Kami, Oyamakui no Kami, Oyamakui no Kami, Amenokoyane no Mikoto and Ukemochi no Kami.

The main deities are Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto (Empress Jingu), Yachitose no Kami (Okuninushi no Kami) and Kunitokotachi no Mikoto which are enshrined with Amaterasu Omikami, Emperor Ojin, Wake-Ikazuchino Kami, Oyamakui no Kami, Oyamakui no Kami, Amenokoyane no Mikoto and Ukemochi no Kami.

The main deities are Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto (Empress Jingu), Yachitose no Kami (Okuninushi no Kami) and Kunitokotachi no Mikoto which are enshrined with Amaterasu Omikami, the Emperor Ojin, Wake-Ikazuchino Kami, Oyamakui no Kami, Amenokoyane no Mikoto and Ukemochi no Kami.
sen.cmt: Oyamakui no Kami,削除"the" を追加しました。

sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 創立年代は不詳である。
sen.e: The specific time of the shrine's founding is unknown.
The specific time of the shrine's founding is unknown.
The specific time of the shrine's founding is unknown.

sen.j: この地にあった式内社「真幡寸神社」に、神功皇后の三韓征伐の際に船上に立てた旗に神功皇后・八千戈神（大国主神）の神霊を添えて奉斎したのに始まると伝える。
sen.e: The shikinaisha (shrine listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) "Mahataki-jinja Shrine" that stood on the site is said to have originated with the dedication of the flag flown during Empress Jingu's Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms to which the spirits of Empress Jingu and Yachitose no Kami (Okuninushi no Kami) had become attached.
sen.cmt: 三韓征伐→Sankanseibatsu, The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms [journals.cambridge.org/production/action/cjoGetFulltext?]
sen.e: The shikinaisha (shrine listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) "Mahataki-jinja Shrine" that stood on the site is said to have originated with the dedication of the flag flown during Empress Jingu's Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms to which the spirits of Empress Jingu and Yachitose no Kami (Okuninushi no Kami) had become attached.

The shikinaisha (shrine listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho) 'Mahataki-jinja Shrine' that stood on the site is said to have originated with the dedication of the flag flown during Empress Jingu's Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms to which the spirits of Empress Jingu and Yachitose no Kami (Okuninushi no Kami) had become attached.

sen.j: 平安京遷都の際に国常立尊が併祀され、城（平安京）の南にあることから「城南神」と称された。
sen.e: Kunitokotachi no Mikoto was enshrined at the time of the relocation of the capital city to Heian-kyo and was named "Jonan no kami" after the location to the south of the castle.
Kunitokotachi no Mikoto was enshrined at the time of the relocation of the capital city to Heian-kyo and was named "Jonan no kami" after the location to the south of the castle.
Kunitokotachi no Mikoto was enshrined at the time of the relocation of the capital city to Heian-kyo and was named 'Jonan no kami' after the location to the south of the castle.

sen.j: 白河天皇が鳥羽離宮（城南離宮）を造営してからはその一部とされ、代々の天皇、上皇がしばしば行幸した。
sen.e: When Toba villa (Jonan villa) was built by Emperor Shirakawa, the shrine became part of the estate and was frequently visited by successive emperors and retired emperors.
When Toba villa (Jonan villa) was built by Emperor Shirakawa, the shrine became part of the estate and was frequently visited by successive emperors and retired emperors.
When Toba villa (Jonan villa) was built by the Emperor Shirakawa, the shrine became part of the estate and was frequently visited by successive emperors and retired emperors.

sen.j: また、貴族の方違の宿所となり、京都御所の鬼門を守る神とされたことから、方除け、厄除けの神として信仰されるようになった
sen.e: The shrine came to offer accommodation for nobles travelling a route that would allow them to avoid the misfortune associated with unlucky directions and it became worshipped as a shrine for warding off evil and the misfortune of unlucky directions as it protected the northeast of Kyoto Imperial Palace.

The shrine came to offer accommodation for nobles travelling a route that would allow them to avoid the misfortune associated with unlucky directions and it became worshipped as a shrine for warding off evil and the misfortune of unlucky directions as it protected the northeast of Kyoto Imperial Palace.

The shrine came to offer accommodation for nobles travelling a route that would allow them to avoid the misfortune associated with unlucky directions and it became worshipped as a shrine for warding off evil and the misfortune of unlucky directions as it protected the northeast of Kyoto Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 応仁の乱などの戦乱で荒廃したが、江戸時代に復興された。
sen.e: It fell into deterioration due to conflicts such as the Onin War but was restored during the Edo period.
It fell into deterioration due to conflicts such as the Onin War but was restored during the Edo period.
It fell into deterioration due to conflicts such as the Onin War but was restored during the Edo period.

sen.j: 幕末には鳥羽伏見の戦いの戦場となった。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period, the shrine served as the battlefield for the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.
At the end of the Edo period, the shrine served as the battlefield for the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.
At the end of the Edo period, the shrine served as the battlefield for the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）に孝明天皇が攘夷祈願に行幸した。
sen.e: Emperor Komei visited the shrine in 1863 to pray for the expulsion of foreigners from Japan.
Emperor Komei visited the shrine in 1863 to pray for the expulsion of foreigners from Japan.
The Emperor Komei visited the shrine in 1863 to pray for the expulsion of foreigners from Japan.

sen.j: 明治10年、式内社「真幡寸神社」に比定され、社名を「真幡寸神社」に改称した。
sen.e: In 1877, Jonan-gu Shrine was determined to be the Mahataki-jinja Shrine listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and its name was changed to "Mahataki-jinja Shrine".

In 1877, Jonan-gu Shrine was determined to be the Mahataki-jinja Shrine listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and its name was changed to "Mahataki-jinja Shrine".

In 1877, Jonan-gu Shrine was determined to be the 'Mahataki-jinja Shrine' listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) and its name was changed to 'Mahataki-jinja Shrine.'

sen.j: 昭和43年に「城南宮」に復し、「真幡寸神社」はその境内摂社として、境内に新たに社殿を設けて奉祀されることになった。
sen.e: In 1948, the name "Jonan-gu Shrine" was restored and a new auxiliary shrine named "Mahataki-jinja Shrine" was built within the precinct.
In 1948, the name "Jonan-gu Shrine" was restored and a new auxiliary shrine named "Mahataki-jinja Shrine" was built within the precinct.
In 1948, the name 'Jonan-gu Shrine' was restored and a new auxiliary shrine named 'Mahataki-jinja Shrine' was built within the precinct.
